body: GENE BERTONCINI A couple of stone's throws from Times Square is Le Madeleine, the unpretentious theater-district bistro off Ninth Avenue, where this quietly brilliant guitarist has a regular gig on Sundays and Mondays, playing jazz and standards and Brazilian music on his nylon-string. It's one of New York's hidden pleasures. He'll be there on New
title: In With the New, Kicking Out the Jams

title: Pop and Rock Listings

body: A bill recently proposed in the City Council and known as Introduction 627 has been heralded by many tenants and housing advocates as a measure that would provide long-overdue protections to renters. It would, for the first time, give tenants the right to sue their landlords in Housing Court for harassing them by making threats, disrupting services
title: Dueling Bills In the Fight Over Housing

body: It began as a brazen robbery and kidnapping in Hells Kitchen on the West Side, as men with guns and a phony police badge hijacked a FedEx tractor-trailer loaded with holiday gifts. title: Hijacking Comes to Little When Robbers Can't Get the Cargo Out

body: Across the city, delis and bodegas are a familiar and vital part of the streetscape, modest places where customers can pick up necessities, a container of milk, a can of soup, a loaf of bread. Amid the goods found in the stores, there is one thing that many owners and employees say they cannot do without: their cats. And it goes beyond cuddly
title: To Dismay Of Inspectors, Prowling Cats Keep Rodents On the Run At City Delis

title: URBAN STUDIES | HOISTING; Grab, Grunt and Lift In a Temple of Muscle

author: Margaret Meehan, a writer and editor, lives in Brooklyn.
body: BY age 23, I had romanced cigarettes, chocolate soufflé, my pet cat and (through the TV screen) James Franco on ''Freaks and Geeks.'' But I had yet to experience an actual human romance. title: MODERN LOVE; That's My Pride Beneath the Love Train

body: IF you're in Napa, would you order a Côte du Rhône syrah? In Italy, would you eat microwavable Chef Boyardee? In Belgium, would you buy a Hershey bar? title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK | LOCAL BEERS; Glasses White With Foam

For as long as many of them can remember, the weathered
title: In Coney Island Creek, Hulk of a Yellow Submarine Sticks Out

body: ''How many of you guys got a hooptee, raise your hand?'' Carlos Caraballo asked his senior auto shop at Automotive High School in Brooklyn. body: THE Brooklyn real estate market has turned into a bundle of contradictions in recent months. body: A MONTH after the mortgage markets started to crumble, mortgage brokers and lawyers say that New Yorkers are finding it harder than ever to get mortgages and are increasingly backing out of deals. This lending slowdown has seemed to affect a broader segment of New York City apartment hunters, many of whom are now waiting to see if prices drop
title: Frustrated New Yorkers Grapple With Loan Rates

title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; In Harm's Way

title: Lunch With a Food Revolutionary: Don't Worry, She'll Bring the Capers

title: On Display, the Agonized Objects and Photos of 9/11

title: Pop

title: Brooklyn Dentist Faces Charges of Lewdness

body: A FEW minutes into the opening reception for an exhibit on the intersection of design and technology at the Chelsea Art Museum, one of the pieces caught fire. The installation, called ''Saws,'' accidentally ignited when one of the work's three chainsaws became caught on a stripped extension cord that dangled over a metal sheet on the floor.

body: VISITING the big city can leave you parched, especially in summer. It's easy to develop a more-than-one-beer thirst as you gamely tramp from museum to museum, from landmark to landmark. title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK: BARGAIN BARS; For Beer Tastes, on Beer Budgets

body: An article on July 18 about a lawsuit by New York State seeking the cleanup of an oil spill in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, misstated the number of defendants. Grant National Memorial Park, with performances from Broadway and Off Broadway plays; an excerpt from ''Lady Sings the Blues,'' featuring blues and jazz
title: Spare Times

There are driving instructions from Manhattan for both the Williamsburg and Queensboro Bridges and walking routes from the L train, which stops
title: HABITATS/Greenpoint, Brooklyn; When the Everyday Becomes Art

body: ONE of the last things a fledgling New York City business wants to do is alienate a powerful city politician. Molinaro, the Staten Island borough president, issued a statement attacking the couple's Staten Island Landfill flavor (which
title: HOME FRONT; What's in a Name? It's a Matter of Taste

Produced by The Village Voice, it crams a good dozen or so of the best and most fashionable bands of the moment into an
title: Pop

body: AND then we came to the end. Let's get this party started! Like children who have eaten too many chocolate crinkles on Christmas Eve, fans of the ''Harry Potter'' series by J. K. Rowling have by now been whipped into a frenzy of anticipation for the 12:01 a.m. release on Saturday of the grand finale, ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows.''
title: Muggle Soirees Herald 'Harry' Finale

body: Most chamber musicians don't look at duct tape and ponder its musical potential. But a limited percussion repertory along with a vivid collective imagination has inspired the four members of the ensemble So Percussion to turn their huge loft studio in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, into an experimental sound factory, where ceramic pots, metal objects and
title: It Makes a Great Sound; Just Watch Out for Spikes

body: Inside the walls and barbed wire fence that largely hides the nondescript facility beside Newtown Creek in Brooklyn, a handful of trailers sit in a cluster surrounded by smaller buildings that belong to Exxon Mobil. It is not much to look at, but Exxon Mobil officials say the operation is slowly eliminating the contamination that has been deep
title: Exxon Mobil Cleanup Effort Continues on 1950 Spill

body: The New York State attorney general's office filed a lawsuit yesterday against Exxon Mobil and four other companies to force them to clean up a 57-year-old oil spill that has polluted the soil beneath Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and left traces of toxic chemicals in nearby Newtown Creek. The spill -- said to be originally almost twice as large as the
title: Suit Seeks Belated Cleanup Of a 57-Year-Old Oil Spill

body: A typical passenger might expect to see certain things when spending $50 for a two-hour cruise, like a wonder of the world, or a leaping dolphin or two. But yesterday, a two-story taxi boat was almost full to capacity with people who spent about that much for a tour of one of New York's most polluted waterways, Newtown Creek. Cameras flickered away
title: A Creek Cruise With Sights Rare, Even to New Yorkers

The Jealous Girlfriends, one of the best new bands in New York, float through soft and erotic clouds of guitar

body: For almost 40 years, the La Guardia recreation center, known in its Lower East Side neighborhood as the Whitehouse, has sat vacant -- abandoned in the middle of a densely populated high-rise public housing complex. The Parks Department said it has no plans to reopen the Whitehouse, in the La Guardia Houses complex, because it believes the
title: Difficult Choices for the Old Rec Center

body: ONE Monday morning, on the way to her office in the basement of the Montauk Club in Park Slope, Louise Crawford passed a man staring up at a tree. Lingering for a moment, she asked him what was so interesting. It turned out that a yellow-throated songbird known as a Nashville warbler, in its northward migration, had made a pit stop in the
title: Cracker-Barrel 2.0

body: ON a Sunday night last month at Daddy's, a bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, more than a dozen people in their 20s and 30s gathered at a professional soiree, drinking frozen margaritas and nibbling store-bought cookies. With their thrift-store inspired clothes and abundant tattoos, they looked as if they could be filmmakers, Web designers, coffee shop
title: A Hipper Crowd of Shushers

body: The News Corporation, owner of The New York Post, bought two weekly newspapers in the Bronx yesterday, giving it a chain of neighborhood papers throughout three New York City boroughs that it hopes will complement The Post. News Corporation did not disclose the price it paid to the owners, David Kiesman and John Collazzi, for The Bronx Times and
title: News Corp. Buys Two Weeklies, Expanding New York City Reach

title: THE LISTINGS

title: SPARE TIMES; Events

body: The bill looked like a shoo-in to pass. After nearly a year of painstaking analysis and tough negotiations, the Bloomberg administration, the City Council, housing advocates, lenders and real estate developers had hashed out a measure intended to revamp a popular tax-break program so it would generate more relatively affordable housing while
title: City's Plans For Housing Flop in Albany

body: Hulking and dormant on the North Brooklyn waterfront, its floors still sticky from a century's toil, the former Domino Sugar refinery was the focus of a hearing yesterday to let residents sound off on whether to give it landmark status and allow a developer to transform it into part of an apartment complex. But the residents and the developer
title: History and Homes May Mix At the Brooklyn Waterfront

body: Bagpipes wailed and drums rattled yesterday as thousands of firefighters in dress blues flooded the streets of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, to pay final respects to Daniel F. Pujdak, the 23-year-old firefighter who fell four stories to his death while battling a fire in Brooklyn last Thursday. The firefighters raised white-gloved hands to their caps in
title: Thousands Gather in Brooklyn for Firefighter's Funeral

body: The line stretched yesterday around the corner and into the Evergreen Funeral Home, past a helmet and a bunker coat, finally ending at an open coffin. Firefighter Daniel F. Pujdak was laid out there in his dress blues, the same uniform worn by a number of those in the slow-moving line. The clothes have no practical use for people who struggle
title: Joining in Solidarity, on the Job and in Sorrow

body: Gonpo Dorjee, 16, arrived in America on May 26. But he has seen little of his new home, New York City. The sights he sees most often are a small swath of the East River and part of the industrial skyline of Greenpoint, Brooklyn -- the view from the window of his room at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan. Gonpo, a native of Lhasa, the capital of
title: From Tibet to New York, a Youth Now Faces a Long Journey to Recovery

body: The former sewing factory at 83 Meserole Street in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is like hundreds of other buildings in the industrial precincts of Brooklyn -- a hulking, century-old brick box lined with big windows, its insides turned into lofts inhabited by designers, musicians and other practitioners of the hipster professions. title: Illegal Lofts Get New Scrutiny After a Firefighter's Death

body: Eliot Spitzer's first legislative session was coming to a fractious close on Thursday night, as he and top lawmakers failed to reach agreement on a wide range of issues as they rushed to finish business for the summer. There appeared to be agreement on a small number of measures. One required suspects indicted on rape charges to take H.I.V. tests.
title: Spitzer and Legislature Sprint to Finish Line

body: Firefighter Daniel F. Pujdak fell to his death yesterday while trying to save an artist's loft less than two miles from the three-story aluminum-sided house in Greenpoint where he was raised. Those two buildings, and the man linked to both of them, tell the story of the shifting dynamics of industrial Brooklyn: working-class neighborhoods settled
title: All Too Quickly, a Lifelong Pursuit Is Cut Short

author: Daryl Khan, Andy Newman and Ethan Wilensky-Lanford contributed reporting.
body: A 23-year-old firefighter was killed in Brooklyn yesterday when he fell four stories while fighting a small blaze ignited by a cigarette that had been left on a windowsill, officials said. The firefighter, Daniel F. Pujdak, fell outside a four-story brick building, a onetime warehouse on the edge of Williamsburg. He landed on the pavement amid the
title: Firefighter Falls 4 Stories to His Death in Brooklyn Fire

title: HABITATS/Greenpoint, Brooklyn; A Mix of Mass-Market and Couture

title: The Handwriting on the Road: An Artist Draws the Flood Line

title: Brooklyn Waterfront Called Endangered Site

body: In a city with few backyards, everyone loves a park -- but not many people consider who is going to pay for all that grass. title: Planned Parks May Cost City Too Much, Group Warns

title: Rubin Caslow, 86, Leader Of a Smoked-Fish Dynasty

body: Patrick Wolf is only 23, but already he is one of Britain's most appealing young singer-songwriters. title: MUSIC REVIEW; An Odd One Cometh (Can You Say Drama?)

title: BASEBALL; Pinstripe Memories: Joe D From Brooklyn Was Living a Dream

body: WHETHER they preferred apartments uptown or downtown, walk-up or doorman buildings, and old or new construction, many New Yorkers agreed on one thing about the Manhattan real estate market in the last year: it was safer to rent than to buy. Some feared that if they bought, the market would fall. Others simply put off the hassle of buying for as
title: When Renters Reach the Breaking Point

body: The great shortage of 2007 in New York's real estate market is not of land, concrete or electricians. It's of tax breaks. For the past five years, nearly every developer building rental apartments who asked the state for tax-free bonds got them. It was a benefit worth millions of dollars a year, and all the developers had to do was set aside 20
title: State Reduces Tax Breaks for Developers

body: On Saturday night nearly 500 people filled Studio B in Brooklyn, in the rather desolate borderland between Williamsburg and Greenpoint. They braved a cold night, a tricky commute and (most daunting of all) expensive booze. Around midnight they got their reward: an exuberant and characteristically baffling set by Gang Gang Dance. Gang Gang Dance is
title: MUSIC REVIEW; Who Knows What It All Means? Just Dance and Feel Hip

body: THE bulletin board above Sgt. Robert Kelly's desk at the 90th Precinct station house in Williamsburg is covered with notes and police sketches, scrawled phone numbers and a map. For the past year and a half, the upper right corner of the board has been occupied by a photograph of a human skull, its hollow eyes peering out hauntingly across the
title: URBAN TACTICS; The John Doe of the Brooklyn Badlands

body: JONES--James Robert, M.D., former Chairman and Professor Emeritus of Obstetrics and Gynecology at New York Medical College, died of cardiac arrest on February 12th, in Naples, FL, at the age of 72. The proud Brooklynite, and long time resident of Mendham, New Jersey, is survived by his wife, Priscilla Cooper Jones, his children Michael (Michele),
title: Paid Notice: Deaths JONES, JAMES ROBERT, M.D.

body: ZIPPER--Jacob, on February 5, 2007, in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Born April 29, 1910, in Zaboike, Galicia (Ukraine). Chazzan and rabbi of Congregation Ahavas Israel in Greenpoint from 1949 to 2007. title: Paid Notice: Deaths ZIPPER, JACOB

body: New York State moved to sue Exxon Mobil and four other companies on Thursday to force them to clean up a half-century-old spill of millions of gallons of oil lying under the Greenpoint neighborhood in Brooklyn and to repair environmental damage inflicted on nearby Newtown Creek. The spill, originally several times the size of the Exxon Valdez oil
title: Cuomo Moves Toward Lawsuit Over a 50-Year-Old Oil Spill in Greenpoint

body: For the nearly 50 years he has managed the Josephs Furniture store in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, Howard Josephs has never forgotten what lurks menacingly below. ''For some people, it is a nonissue, because it's not something you have to confront every day,'' Mr. Josephs said yesterday of the plume of gas and toxic chemicals that has been under
title: After Waiting So Long, Neighbors Are Skeptical

body: A FOX BUSINESS CHANNEL -- Rupert Murdoch announced that the News Corporation would start a long-awaited business news channel in the fourth quarter of this year. He also vowed that the new channel would be friendlier to corporations than CNBC, the leading television business news outlet. [Page C1.] GAUGING DERIVATIVES -- The calm demeanor of
title: TODAY IN BUSINESS

body: He won over the teeny-boppers long ago, but in his incarnation as a sexy-smooth crooner with a hip-hop edge, Justin Timberlake has gained some unusual fans: hipsters. Youthful urbanites who normally wouldn't admit to filling their iPods with anything remotely Top 40, let alone the music of a performer who can sell out Madison Square Garden, as Mr.
title: Timberlake, Pop Juggernaut, Is Gaining Some Unusual Fans

body: There is no cold like the cold after a big New York City fire. The flames take everything that is soft and warm, and then they take the walls and the roof, letting in the black winter sky and the wind off the water so cold it sears before it numbs. Below-freezing temperatures wrap the metropolitan region this week, and the city pads itself and
title: From Searing Flames, a Bleak, Cold Landscape

body: Nobody was supposed to show up for the Idiotarod, the annual absurdist shopping cart race, until 1 p.m. last Saturday. The race's starting point was a closely guarded secret until the day before, and the Carts of Brooklyn Racing Association, its sponsor, had urged people gathering for the 1:30 start time to keep a low profile. At 12:45, though,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Olympics For Hipsters: The Indy 500 It's Not

body: Few shows force you to rethink an urban legend. That's the challenge posed by ''Robert Moses and the Modern City,'' a sweeping, scholarly exhibition that breathes fresh air into one of the most tired, overworked and misunderstood subjects in the city's history. Shown at three New York locations, the exhibition traces Moses' remarkable career as
title: EXHIBITION REVIEW; Complex, Contradictory Robert Moses

body: Gritty freight trains may be a familiar sight out West and in cowboy movies, but in Queens and Brooklyn and the neat suburbs of Long Island, they are a roaring, sooty cause for a big double take. ''We go through here every day, and everyone still looks at us like 'What the heck is this?' '' said Tom Materka, a rail freight engineer, as the train
title: Mystery Trains With Boxcars Instead of Commuters

The brothers have a classic bubble-gum sound, live in a very 21st-century video world and are the real-life offspring of entertainers from two television
title: A TV Family Bound By Blood and a Band

body: Betty Trezza, who at 17 escaped her job as a Garment District embroiderer to play women's professional baseball and went on to smack a memorable championship-winning hit, died Tuesday in the Brooklyn house where she was born. She was 82. The cause was a heart attack, her nephew Jan Perrone said. Madonna did not play a character based on the
title: Betty Trezza, 82, Pioneer of Women's Baseball, Is Dead

body: When Amanda M. Burden's stepfather, William S. Paley, built the vest-pocket park that bears his name on East 53rd Street, he saw to it that the four wide stone steps from the street, each only five inches high, stood as an invitation to enter. Those steps ''are just perfect,'' Ms. Burden recently recalled her mentor, the urban scholar William H.
title: Once at Cotillions, Now Reshaping the Cityscape

body: IF the owners of the Anchor, a lounge on Spring Street in the West Village that opened two weeks ago, were hoping to create something other than a downtown hot spot, they seem to have taken all the necessary precautions. The Anchor, a moodily lit cubbyhole with an Americana theme, has no sign, no bouncer, no bottle service and no velvet rope. The
title: Come to Our Club. Or Not. Whatever.

body: 'ADVENTURES FROM EZRA JACK KEATS: APT. 3 AND MAGGIE AND THE PIRATE' (Tonight through Monday) Two books by this author and illustrator come to life onstage in the winter musical from Tada!, the youth theater troupe. ''Apt. 3'' focuses on the friendship that two children forge with a blind neighbor; ''Maggie and the Pirate'' is about, well, a girl
title: SPARE TIMES: Jan. 12 - Jan. 18; For Children

body: Even in a city full of talented people with eclectic interests, Irving Feller's combination of work and obsession stands out. Mr. Feller is a furrier by trade and an abstract artist out of love. He can make a sumptuous fur coat from scratch as easily as he can create jarring works of pattern and color. And both pursuits are informed by his passion
title: GREENPOINT JOURNAL; A Brooklyn Furrier and Artist Finds Soul Mates Among the Indians of the West
